decision_conditions: The Oak tree can be viewed from between the properties (44 and 42) and the hornbeams can be seen above the property. The trees form a group which has a moderate amenity value.
The trees do not appear to have been pruned (crown reduced) before and have attractive, natural-looking crowns typical of their species.

Along with other nearby trees the Oak and Hornbeams help to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in Copsewood Way and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR)
The trees contributes to local biodiversity, and to the amenity and arboreal / wooded character of the Copsewood Estate Area of Special Local Character.

The applicant has requested to carry out the proposed work to "reduce shading of house" however the trees are located on the North/ North West side of the property and as a result reductions are unlikely to significantly reduce shading on the property.  The trees appear to be in good health and pruning them would unnecessa
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.
description: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown reduction by 3m, to one oak, (T1 on application), a crown reduction by 6m, to one Hornbeam group (T3 on application), within Area 1 on TPO 399.
